translation.author: Wahiduddin Khan
translation.text: We delivered Moses and all those who were with him,

translation.author: Yusuf Ali
translation.text: We delivered Moses and all who were with him;

translation.author: Ahmed Ali
translation.text: The mother of Moses was perturbed in the morning. Had We not strengthened her heart to remain a believer she had almost given him away.

translation.author: Arberry
translation.text: On the morrow the heart of Moses" mother became empty, and she wellnigh disclosed him had We not strengthened her heart, that she might be among the believers;

translation.author: Daryabadi
translation.text: And the heart of the mother of Musa became void, and she had wellnigh disclosed him, had We not fortified her heart, that she might remain one of the believers.

translation.author: Hilali & Khan
translation.text: And the heart of the mother of Musa (Moses) became empty [from every thought, except the thought of Musa (Moses)]. She was very near to disclose his (case, i.e. the child is her son), had We not strengthened her heart (with Faith), so that she might remain as one of the believers.

translation.author: Itani
translation.text: The heart of Moses’ mother became vacant. She was about to disclose him, had We not steadied her heart, that she may remain a believer.

translation.author: Maududi
translation.text: On the other hand, the heart of Moses' mother was sorely distressed. Had We not strengthened her heart that she might have full faith (in Our promise), she would have disclosed the secret.

translation.author: Mubarakpuri
translation.text: And the heart of the mother of Musa became empty. She was very near to disclose his (case), had We not strengthened her heart, so that she might remain as one of the believers.

translation.author: Pickthall
translation.text: And the heart of the mother of Moses became void, and she would have betrayed him if We had not fortified her heart, that she might be of the believers.

translation.author: Qarai
translation.text: The heart of Moses’ mother became desolate, and indeed she was about to divulge it had We not fortified her heart so that she might have faith [in Allah’s promise].

translation.author: Qaribullah & Darwish
translation.text: In the morning the heart of Moses' mother became empty. She would have revealed (who he was) had We not settled her heart so that she might be among the believers.

translation.author: Saheeh International
translation.text: And the heart of Moses' mother became empty [of all else]. She was about to disclose [the matter concerning] him had We not bound fast her heart that she would be of the believers.

translation.author: Sarwar
translation.text: The heart of Moses' mother was relieved and confident. But she would almost have made the whole matter public had We not strengthened her heart with faith.

translation.author: Wahiduddin Khan
translation.text: Moses' mother's heart was full of anxiety -- she would have disclosed his identity had We not strengthened her heart so that she might be a firm believer [in Our promise].

translation.author: Yusuf Ali
translation.text: But there came to be a void in the heart of the mother of Moses: She was going almost to disclose his (case), had We not strengthened her heart (with faith), so that she might remain a (firm) believer.

translation.author: Ahmed Ali
translation.text: The Pharaoh said: "O nobles, I am not aware of any other lord of yours but myself. So, O Haman, fire some clay (bricks) to build a tower for me that I may mount up (and see) the God of Moses; for I think he is a liar."

translation.author: Arberry
translation.text: And Pharaoh said, 'Council, I know not that you have any god but me. Kindle me, Haman, a fire upon the clay, and make me a tower, that I may mount up to Moses' god; for I think that he is one of the liars.'

translation.author: Daryabadi
translation.text: And Fir'awn said: O chiefs! know not of a god for you except me. Wherefore light thou for me, O Haman! clay, and make me a lofty tower that I may ascend unto the God of Musa; and verily I imagine him to be of the liars.

translation.author: Hilali & Khan
translation.text: Fir'aun (Pharaoh) said: "O chiefs! I know not that you have an ilah (a god) other than me, so kindle for me (a fire), O Haman, to bake (bricks out of) clay, and set up for me a Sarhan (a lofty tower, or palace, etc.) in order that I may look at (or look for) the Ilah (God) of Musa (Moses); and verily, I think that he [Musa (Moses)] is one of the liars."

translation.author: Itani
translation.text: Pharaoh said, “O nobles, I know of no god for you other than me. So fire-up the bricks for me O Hamaan, and build me a tower, that I may ascend to the God of Moses, though I think he is a liar.”

translation.author: Maududi
translation.text: Pharaoh said: "O nobles, I do not know that you have any god beside myself. Haman, bake bricks out of clay and build a lofty palace for me so that I may mount up and be able to observe the god of Moses, even though I believe that Moses is a liar."

translation.author: Mubarakpuri
translation.text: Fir`awn said: "O chiefs! I know not that you have a god other than me. So kindle for me (a fire), O Haman, to bake clay, and set up for me a Sarh in order that I may look at the God of Musa; and verily, I think that he (Musa) is one of the liars."

translation.author: Pickthall
translation.text: And Pharaoh said: O chiefs! I know not that ye have a god other than me, so kindle for me (a fire), O Haman, to bake the mud; and set up for me a lofty tower in order that I may survey the god of Moses; and lo! I deem him of the liars.

translation.author: Qarai
translation.text: Pharaoh said, ‘O [members of the] elite! I do not know of any god that you may have besides me. Haman, light for me a fire over clay, and build me a tower so that I may take a look at Moses’ god, and indeed I consider him to be a liar!’

translation.author: Qaribullah & Darwish
translation.text: 'Assembly' said Pharaoh, 'I do not know that you have any god except me' 'O Haman, kindle a fire upon clay and make me a tower so that I can climb to see the God of Moses, I think that he is one of the liars'

translation.author: Saheeh International
translation.text: And Pharaoh said, "O eminent ones, I have not known you to have a god other than me. Then ignite for me, O Haman, [a fire] upon the clay and make for me a tower that I may look at the God of Moses. And indeed, I do think he is among the liars."

translation.author: Sarwar
translation.text: The Pharaoh said, "My people, I know no one who could be your lord besides myself. Haman, construct for me a tower of baked bricks so that I may climb on it and see the God of Moses; I think he is a liar."

translation.author: Wahiduddin Khan
translation.text: Pharaoh said, "O nobles, I know of no god for you other than myself. So, Haman, burn me bricks of clay, and build me a high tower, so that I may have a look at the God of Moses, though I consider him to be one of the liars."

translation.author: Yusuf Ali
translation.text: Pharaoh said: "O Chiefs! no god do I know for you but myself: therefore, O Haman! light me a (kiln to bake bricks) out of clay, and build me a lofty palace, that I may mount up to the god of Moses: but as far as I am concerned, I think (Moses) is a liar!"

translation.author: Ahmed Ali
translation.text: You were not there on the western side (of Mount Sinai) when We gave the commandments to Moses, nor were you witness (to the event).

translation.author: Arberry
translation.text: Thou wast not upon the western side when We decreed to Moses the commandment, nor wast thou of those witnessing;

translation.author: Daryabadi
translation.text: And thou wast not on the western side when We decreed the affair unto Musa, and thou wast not of the witnesses.

translation.author: Hilali & Khan
translation.text: And you (O Muhammad SAW) were not on the western side (of the Mount), when We made clear to Musa (Moses) the commandment, and you were not among those present.

translation.author: Itani
translation.text: You were not on the Western Side when We decreed the command to Moses, nor were you among the witnesses.

translation.author: Mubarakpuri
translation.text: And you were not on the western side (of the Mount), when We made clear to Musa the commandment, and you were not among the witnesses.

translation.author: Pickthall
translation.text: And thou (Muhammad) wast not on the western side (of the Mount) when We expounded unto Moses the commandment, and thou wast not among those present;

translation.author: Qarai
translation.text: You were not on the western side when We revealed the commandments to Moses, nor were you among the witnesses.

translation.author: Qaribullah & Darwish
translation.text: (Prophet Muhammad) you were not on the western side (of the mountain) when We decreed the commandment to Moses, nor were you among thosewitnessing.

translation.author: Saheeh International
translation.text: And you, [O Muhammad], were not on the western side [of the mount] when We revealed to Moses the command, and you were not among the witnesses [to that].

translation.author: Sarwar
translation.text: (Muhammad), you were not present at the west bank to witness when We gave the commandments to Moses.

translation.author: Shakir
translation.text: And you were not on the western side when We revealed to Musa the commandment, and you were not among the witnesses;

translation.author: Wahiduddin Khan
translation.text: You were not present on the western side of the Mount when We gave Our Command to Moses: nor were you among the witnesses,

translation.author: Yusuf Ali
translation.text: Thou wast not on the Western side when We decreed the Commission to Moses, nor wast thou a witness (of those events).

translation.author: Ahmed Ali
translation.text: So We conveyed to the mother of Moses: "Suckle him. If you are afraid for him, cast him in the river without any fear or regret, for We shall restore him to you, and make him an apostle."

translation.author: Arberry
translation.text: So We revealed to Moses' mother, 'Suckle him, then, when thou fearest for him, cast him into the sea, and do not fear, neither sorrow, for We shall return him to thee, and shall appoint him one of the Envoys.'

translation.author: Daryabadi
translation.text: And We inspired the mother of Musa, saying: suckle him, then when thou fearest for him, cast him into the river and fear not, nor grieve. Verily We are going to restore him unto thee, and shall make him one of the sent ones.

translation.author: Hilali & Khan
translation.text: And We inspired the mother of Musa (Moses), (saying): "Suckle him [Musa (Moses)], but when you fear for him, then cast him into the river and fear not, nor grieve. Verily! We shall bring him back to you, and shall make him one of (Our) Messengers."

translation.author: Itani
translation.text: We inspired the mother of Moses: “Nurse him; then, when you fear for him, cast him into the river, and do not fear, nor grieve; We will return him to you, and make him one of the messengers.”

translation.author: Maududi
translation.text: We suggested to the mother of Moses: "Suckle your child, but when you fear for his life cast him into the river and be not fearful nor grieve, for We shall restore him to you and make him one of the Messengers."

translation.author: Mubarakpuri
translation.text: And We inspired the mother of Musa: "Suckle him (Musa), but when you fear for him, then cast him into the river and fear not, nor grieve. Verily, We shall bring him back to you, and shall make him one of the Messengers."

translation.author: Pickthall
translation.text: And We inspired the mother of Moses, saying: Suckle him and, when thou fearest for him, then cast him into the river and fear not nor grieve. Lo! We shall bring him back unto thee and shall make him (one) of Our messengers.

translation.author: Qarai
translation.text: We revealed to Moses’ mother, [saying], ‘Nurse him; then, when you fear for him, cast him into the river, and do not fear or grieve, for We will restore him to you and make him one of the apostles.’

translation.author: Qaribullah & Darwish
translation.text: We revealed this to Moses' mother: 'Suckle him, but when you fear for him cast him into the water. Neither fear, nor sorrow because We shall restore him to you and make him among the Messengers'

translation.author: Saheeh International
translation.text: And We inspired to the mother of Moses, "Suckle him; but when you fear for him, cast him into the river and do not fear and do not grieve. Indeed, We will return him to you and will make him [one] of the messengers."

translation.author: Sarwar
translation.text: We inspired Moses' mother saying, "Breast-feed your son. When you become afraid for his life, throw him into the sea. Do not be afraid or grieved for We shall return him to you and make him a Messenger."

translation.author: Wahiduddin Khan
translation.text: We inspired Moses' mother saying, "Suckle him, and then, when you fear for him, cast him into the river, and have no fear and do not grieve, for We shall return him to you, and shall make him one of the Messengers."

translation.author: Yusuf Ali
translation.text: So We sent this inspiration to the mother of Moses: "Suckle (thy child), but when thou hast fears about him, cast him into the river, but fear not nor grieve: for We shall restore him to thee, and We shall make him one of Our messengers."

translation.author: Ahmed Ali
translation.text: Verily Qarun was of Moses' people, but he began to oppress them. We had given him treasures, so many that a team of wrestlers could hardly lift their keys. His people said to him: "Do not be exultant. God does not like those who exult.

translation.author: Arberry
translation.text: Now Korah was of the people of Moses; he became insolent to them, for We had given him treasures such that the very keys of them were too heavy a burden for a company of men endowed with strength. When his people said to him, 'Do not exult; God loves not those that exult;

translation.author: Daryabadi
translation.text: Verily Qarun was of the people of Musa; then he behaved arrogantly toward them. And We had vouchsafed him of the treasures whereof the keys would have weighed down a band of strong men. Recall what time his people said unto him: exult not; verily God loveth not the exultant.

translation.author: Hilali & Khan
translation.text: Verily, Qarun (Korah) was of Musa's (Moses) people, but he behaved arrogantly towards them. And We gave him of the treasures, that of which the keys would have been a burden to a body of strong men. When his people said to him: "Do not be glad (with ungratefulness to Allah's Favours). Verily! Allah likes not those who are glad (with ungratefulness to Allah's Favours).

translation.author: Itani
translation.text: Quaroon belonged to the clan of Moses, but he oppressed them. We had given him treasures, the keys of which would weigh down a group of strong men. His people said to him, “Do not exult; God does not love the exultant.

translation.author: Maududi
translation.text: To be sure, Qarun (Korah) was one of Moses' people; then he transgressed against them. We had bestowed on him such treasure that their very keys would have been raised with difficulty by a whole group of strong people. Once when his people said to him: "Do not exult, for Allah does not love those who exult (in their riches).

translation.author: Pickthall
translation.text: Now Korah was of Moses' folk, but he oppressed them; and We gave him so much treasure that the stores thereof would verily have been a burden for a troop of mighty men. When his own folk said unto him: Exult not; lo! Allah loveth not the exultant;

translation.author: Qarai
translation.text: Korah indeed belonged to the people of Moses, but he bullied them. We had given him so much treasures that their chests indeed proved heavy for a band of stalwarts. When his people said to him, ‘Do not boast! Indeed Allah does not like the boasters.

translation.author: Qaribullah & Darwish
translation.text: . Korah was one of Moses' nation. But he was insolent to them, for We had given him such treasures that their very keys were too heavy a burden for even the strong. His people said to him: 'Do not exult; Allah does not love the boastful.

translation.author: Saheeh International
translation.text: Indeed, Qarun was from the people of Moses, but he tyrannized them. And We gave him of treasures whose keys would burden a band of strong men; thereupon his people said to him, "Do not exult. Indeed, Allah does not like the exultant.

translation.author: Sarwar
translation.text: Korah was a man from the people of Moses. This man rebelled against them. We had given him so much treasure that the keys of the stores of his treasures could hardly even be carried by a group of strong people. His people told him, "Do not be proud of your wealth; God does not love those who are proudly happy of their wealth.

translation.author: Shakir
translation.text: Surely Qaroun was of the people of Musa, but he rebelled against them, and We had given him of the treasures, so much so that his hoards of wealth would certainly weigh down a company of men possessed of great strength. When his people said to him: Do not exult, surely Allah does not love the exultant;

translation.author: Wahiduddin Khan
translation.text: Korah was one of Moses' people, but he behaved arrogantly towards them. We had given him such treasures that their very keys would have weighed down a band of strong men. His people said to him, "Do not exult in your riches, for God does not love the exultant.

translation.author: Yusuf Ali
translation.text: Qarun was doubtless, of the people of Moses; but he acted insolently towards them: such were the treasures We had bestowed on him that their very keys would have been a burden to a body of strong men, behold, his people said to him: "Exult not, for Allah loveth not those who exult (in riches).

translation.author: Ahmed Ali
translation.text: We said to Moses: "Throw down your staff;" and it swallowed up their conjurations in no time.

translation.author: Arberry
translation.text: And We revealed to Moses: 'Cast thy staff!' And lo, it forthwith swallowed up their lying invention.

translation.author: Daryabadi
translation.text: And we revealed unto Musa: cast down thy rod. And lo! it Was swallowing up that which they had feigned.

translation.author: Hilali & Khan
translation.text: And We inspired Musa (Moses) (saying): "Throw your stick," and behold! It swallowed up straight away all the falsehoods which they showed.

translation.author: Itani
translation.text: And We inspired Moses: “Throw your staff.” And at once, it swallowed what they were faking.

translation.author: Maududi
translation.text: Then We directed Moses: 'Now you throw your rod.' And lo! it swallowed up all their false devices.

translation.author: Mubarakpuri
translation.text: And We revealed to Musa (saying): "Throw your stick," and behold! It swallowed up straight away all the falsehood which they showed.

translation.author: Pickthall
translation.text: And We inspired Moses (saying): Throw thy staff! And lo! it swallowed up their lying show.

translation.author: Qarai
translation.text: And We signalled to Moses: ‘Throw down your staff.’ And behold, it was swallowing what they had faked.

translation.author: Qaribullah & Darwish
translation.text: Then We revealed to Moses: 'Now, throw down your staff' And thereupon it swallowed up their false invention.

translation.author: Saheeh International
translation.text: And We inspired to Moses, "Throw your staff," and at once it devoured what they were falsifying.

translation.author: Sarwar
translation.text: We inspired Moses to throw his staff, and suddenly it began to swallow-up all that the magicians had (falsely) invented.

translation.author: Shakir
translation.text: And We revealed to Musa, saying: Cast your rod; then lo! it devoured the lies they told.

translation.author: Wahiduddin Khan
translation.text: Then We inspired Moses, saying, "Throw down your staff." And it immediately swallowed up their false devices.

translation.author: Ahmed Ali
translation.text: In the absence of Moses his people prepared the image of a calf from their ornaments, which gave out the mooing of a cow. Yet they did not see it could neither speak to them nor guide them to the right path. Even then they took it (for a deity) and did wrong.

translation.author: Arberry
translation.text: And the people of Moses took to them, after him, of their ornaments a Calf -- a mere body that lowed. Did they not see it spoke not to them, neither guided them upon any way? Yet they took it to them, and were evildoers.

translation.author: Daryabadi
translation.text: And ehe people of Musa, after him, took of their trinkets a calf: a body with a low. Saw they not that it spake nor unto them nor could guide them to a way? They took it, and became wrong-doers.

translation.author: Hilali & Khan
translation.text: And the people of Musa (Moses) made in his absence, out of their ornaments, the image of a calf (for worship). It had a sound (as if it was mooing). Did they not see that it could neither speak to them nor guide them to the way? They took it for worship and they were Zalimun (wrong-doers).

translation.author: Itani
translation.text: In his absence, the people of Moses adopted a calf made from their ornaments—a body which lowed. Did they not see that it could not speak to them, nor guide them in any way? They took it for worship. They were in the wrong.

translation.author: Maududi
translation.text: And in the absence of Moses his people made the image of a calf from their ornaments, which lowed. Did they not observe that it could neither speak nor give them any guidance? And still they made it an object of worship. They were indeed wrong-doing.

translation.author: Mubarakpuri
translation.text: And the people of Musa made in his absence, out of their ornaments, the image of a calf (for worship). It had a sound. Did they not see that it could neither speak to them nor guide them to the way They took it (for worship) and they were wrongdoers.

translation.author: Pickthall
translation.text: And the folk of Moses, after (he left them), chose a calf (for worship), (made) out of their ornaments, of saffron hue, which gave a lowing sound. Saw they not that it spake not unto them nor guided them to any way? They chose it, and became wrong-doers.

translation.author: Qarai
translation.text: The people of Moses took up in his absence a calf [cast] from their ornaments—a body that gave out a lowing sound. Did they not regard that it did not speak to them, nor did it guide them to any way? They took it up [for worship] and they were wrongdoers.

translation.author: Qaribullah & Darwish
translation.text: In his absence, the nation of Moses made a calf from their ornaments, a body with a hollow sound. Did they not see that it could neither speak to them, nor guide them to a path? Yet they took it in worship and were harmdoers.

translation.author: Saheeh International
translation.text: And the people of Moses made, after [his departure], from their ornaments a calf - an image having a lowing sound. Did they not see that it could neither speak to them nor guide them to a way? They took it [for worship], and they were wrongdoers.

translation.author: Sarwar
translation.text: In Moses' absence, his people manufactured a hollow sounding calf out of their ornaments. Could they not see that it could not speak to them or provide them with any guidance? They gained only evil by worshipping the calf.

translation.author: Wahiduddin Khan
translation.text: In his absence, the people of Moses made a calf from their ornaments, an image which made a lowing sound. Could they not see that it did not speak to them or guide them in any way? Yet they took to worshipping it: they were evil-doers.

translation.author: Yusuf Ali
translation.text: The people of Moses made, in his absence, out of their ornaments, the image of calf, (for worship): it seemed to low: did they not see that it could neither speak to them, nor show them the way? They took it for worship and they did wrong.

translation.author: Ahmed Ali
translation.text: When his anger subsided Moses picked up the tablets. Inscribed on them was guidance and grace for those who fear their Lord.

translation.author: Arberry
translation.text: And when Moses' anger abated in him, he took the Tablets and in the inscription of them was guidance, and mercy unto all those who hold their Lord in awe.

translation.author: Daryabadi
translation.text: And when the indignation of Musa was appeased, he took up the tablets, and in the inscription thereon were guidance and mercy unto these who dread their Lord.

translation.author: Hilali & Khan
translation.text: And when the anger of Musa (Moses) was appeased, he took up the Tablets, and in their inscription was guidance and mercy for those who fear their Lord.

translation.author: Itani
translation.text: When the anger abated in Moses, he took up the tablets. In their transcript is guidance and mercy for those in awe of their Lord.

translation.author: Maududi
translation.text: And when the anger of Moses was stilled, he took up the Tablets again, the text of which comprised guidance and mercy to those who fear their Lord.

translation.author: Mubarakpuri
translation.text: And when the anger of Musa calmed, he took up the Tablets; and in their inscription was guidance and mercy for those who fear their Lord.

translation.author: Pickthall
translation.text: Then, when the anger of Moses abated, he took up the tablets, and in their inscription there was guidance and mercy for all those who fear their Lord.

translation.author: Qarai
translation.text: When Moses’ indignation abated, he picked up the tablets whose inscriptions contained guidance and mercy for those who are in awe of their Lord.

translation.author: Qaribullah & Darwish
translation.text: When his anger abated, Moses took up the Tablets upon which was inscribed guidance and mercy to those who fear their Lord.

translation.author: Saheeh International
translation.text: And when the anger subsided in Moses, he took up the tablets; and in their inscription was guidance and mercy for those who are fearful of their Lord.

translation.author: Sarwar
translation.text: When Moses' anger calmed down, he collected the Tablets. On one of them was written, "God's mercy and guidance are for those who have fear of Him."

translation.author: Wahiduddin Khan
translation.text: When his anger had subsided, Moses took up the Tablets upon which was inscribed a pledge of guidance and mercy for those who fear their Lord.

translation.author: Yusuf Ali
translation.text: When the anger of Moses was appeased, he took up the tablets: in the writing thereon was guidance and Mercy for such as fear their Lord.

translation.author: Ahmed Ali
translation.text: Among the people of Moses is a section that shows the way to the truth, and deals justly in accordance with it.

translation.author: Arberry
translation.text: Of the people of Moses there is a nation who guide by the truth, and by it act with justice.

translation.author: Daryabadi
translation.text: And of the people of Musa there is a community guiding others by the truth and judging thereby.

translation.author: Hilali & Khan
translation.text: And of the people of Musa (Moses) there is a community who lead (the men) with truth and establish justice therewith (i.e. judge men with truth and justice).

translation.author: Itani
translation.text: Among the people of Moses is a community that guides by truth, and thereby does justice.

translation.author: Maududi
translation.text: Among the people of Moses' there was a party who guided others in the way of the truth and established justice in its light.

translation.author: Mubarakpuri
translation.text: And of the people of Musa there is a community who lead (the men) with truth and establish justice therewith.

translation.author: Pickthall
translation.text: And of Moses' folk there is a community who lead with truth and establish justice therewith.

translation.author: Qarai
translation.text: Among the people of Moses is a nation who guide [the people] by the truth and do justice thereby.

translation.author: Qaribullah & Darwish
translation.text: Yet among the people of Moses there was a nation who preached the truth and acted justly.

translation.author: Saheeh International
translation.text: And among the people of Moses is a community which guides by truth and by it establishes justice.

translation.author: Sarwar
translation.text: Among the people of Moses are some whose guidance and Judgment are based on the Truth.

translation.author: Wahiduddin Khan
translation.text: Yet there is a group among the people of Moses who guide with truth and act justly in accordance with it.

translation.author: Yusuf Ali
translation.text: Of the people of Moses there is a section who guide and do justice in the light of truth.

translation.author: Ahmed Ali
translation.text: When they went back to Joseph he gave his father and mother a place of honour, and said: "Enter Egypt in peace by the will of God."

translation.author: Ahmed Raza Khan
translation.text: So when they all reached in Yusuf’s company, he kept his parents close to him, and said, “Enter Egypt, if Allah wills, in safety.”

translation.author: Arberry
translation.text: So, when they entered unto Joseph, he took his father and mother into his arms saying, 'Enter you into Egypt, if God will, in security.'

translation.author: Hilali & Khan
translation.text: Then, when they entered unto Yusuf (Joseph), he betook his parents to himself and said: "Enter Egypt, if Allah wills, in security."

translation.author: Itani
translation.text: Then, when they entered into the presence of Joseph, he embraced his parents, and said, “Enter Egypt, God willing, safe and secure.”

translation.author: Mubarakpuri
translation.text: Then, when they came in before Yusuf, he took his parents to himself and said: "Enter Egypt, if Allah wills, in security."

translation.author: Pickthall
translation.text: And when they came in before Joseph, he took his parents unto him, and said: Come into Egypt safe, if Allah will!

translation.author: Qarai
translation.text: When they entered into the presence of Joseph, he set his parents close to himself, and said, ‘Welcome to Egypt, in safety, God willing!’

translation.author: Qaribullah & Darwish
translation.text: And when they entered before Joseph, he took his father and mother into his arms and said: 'Welcome to Egypt, safe, if Allah wills'

translation.author: Saheeh International
translation.text: And when they entered upon Joseph, he took his parents to himself and said, "Enter Egypt, Allah willing, safe [and secure]."

translation.author: Shakir
translation.text: Then when they came in to Yusuf, he took his parents to lodge with him and said: Enter safe into Egypt, if Allah please.

translation.author: Wahiduddin Khan
translation.text: Then, when they presented themselves before Joseph, he drew his parents to him and said, "Welcome to Egypt, in safety, if God wills!"

translation.author: Yusuf Ali
translation.text: Then when they entered the presence of Joseph, he provided a home for his parents with himself, and said: "Enter ye Egypt (all) in safety if it please Allah."

translation.author: Ahmed Ali
translation.text: He replied: "You know that none but the Lord of the heavens and the earth has sent these (signs) as cogent proof. I truly think, O Pharaoh, your days are done."

translation.author: Arberry
translation.text: He said, 'Indeed thou knowest that none sent these down, except the Lord of the heavens and earth, as clear proofs; and, Pharaoh, I think thou art accursed.'

translation.author: Daryabadi
translation.text: Musa said: assuredly thou knowest that none hath sent down these save the Lord of the heavens and the earth as an enlightenment; and verily imagine thee, Fir'awn, doomed.

translation.author: Hilali & Khan
translation.text: [Musa (Moses)] said: "Verily, you know that these signs have been sent down by none but the Lord of the heavens and the earth as clear (evidences i.e. proofs of Allah's Oneness and His Omnipotence, etc.). And I think you are, indeed, O Fir'aun (Pharaoh) doomed to destruction (away from all good)!"

translation.author: Itani
translation.text: He said, “You know that none sent these down except the Lord of the heavens and the earth—eye openers; and I think that you, Pharaoh, are doomed.”

translation.author: Maududi
translation.text: Moses replied: "You know well that no one but the Lord of the heavens and the earth has sent these as eye-opening proofs. I truly think, O Pharaoh, that you are indeed doomed."

translation.author: Pickthall
translation.text: He said: In truth thou knowest that none sent down these (portents) save the Lord of the heavens and the earth as proofs, and lo! (for my part) I deem thee lost, O Pharaoh.

translation.author: Qarai
translation.text: He said, ‘You certainly know that no one has sent these [signs] except the Lord of the heavens and the earth, as eye-openers, and I, O Pharaoh, indeed think you are doomed.’

translation.author: Qaribullah & Darwish
translation.text: 'You know' he replied, 'that none except the Lord of the heavens and the earth has sent down these as clear proofs. Pharaoh, I believe you are destroyed.'

translation.author: Saheeh International
translation.text: [Moses] said, "You have already known that none has sent down these [signs] except the Lord of the heavens and the earth as evidence, and indeed I think, O Pharaoh, that you are destroyed."

translation.author: Sarwar
translation.text: He replied, "Certainly you have come to know that these have been sent by the Lord of the heavens and the earth as lessons to people. Pharaoh, I believe that you are doomed to perdition.

translation.author: Wahiduddin Khan
translation.text: He said, "You know full well that none has sent down these signs but the Lord of the heavens and the earth as eye-opening evidence. Indeed, Pharaoh, I can see that you are doomed."

translation.author: Yusuf Ali
translation.text: Moses said, "Thou knowest well that these things have been sent down by none but the Lord of the heavens and the earth as eye-opening evidence: and I consider thee indeed, O Pharaoh, to be one doomed to destruction!"

translation.author: Ahmed Ali
translation.text: Said (Moses): "Let your meeting be on the day of the Feast, and let people assemble in broad daylight."

translation.author: Arberry
translation.text: 'Your tryst shall be upon the Feast Day.' said Moses. 'Let the people be mustered at the high noon.'

translation.author: Daryabadi
translation.text: Musa said: your appointment is the gala day, and that the people be gathered in the forenoon.

translation.author: Hilali & Khan
translation.text: [Musa (Moses)] said: "Your appointed meeting is the day of the festival, and let the people assemble when the sun has risen (forenoon)."

translation.author: Maududi
translation.text: Moses said: "The appointment to meet you is on the Day of the Feast and let all people come together before noon."

translation.author: Mubarakpuri
translation.text: (Musa) said: "Your appointed meeting is the day of the festival, and let the people assemble when the sun has risen (forenoon)."

translation.author: Pickthall
translation.text: (Moses) said: Your tryst shall be the day of the feast, and let the people assemble when the sun hath risen high.

translation.author: Qaribullah & Darwish
translation.text: He (Moses) replied: 'Your meeting shall be on the day of the feast, and let the people be assembled by midmorning'

translation.author: Saheeh International
translation.text: [Moses] said, "Your appointment is on the day of the festival when the people assemble at mid-morning."

translation.author: Sarwar
translation.text: Moses said, "Let the contest take place on the Day of Feast so that all the people can come together during the brightness of the day."

translation.author: Shakir
translation.text: (Musa) said: Your appointment is the day of the Festival and let the people be gathered together in the early forenoon.

translation.author: Wahiduddin Khan
translation.text: Moses said, "The day of the encounter will be the day of the festival, and let the people assemble when the sun has risen high."

translation.author: Yusuf Ali
translation.text: Moses said: "Your tryst is the Day of the Festival, and let the people be assembled when the sun is well up."

translation.author: Ahmed Ali
translation.text: But (Moses) said: "O Aaron, when you saw that they had gone astray, what hindered you

translation.author: Arberry
translation.text: Moses said, 'What prevented thee, Aaron, when thou sawest them in error,

translation.author: Daryabadi
translation.text: Musa said: O Harun! what prevented thee, when thou sawest them going astray.

translation.author: Hilali & Khan
translation.text: [Musa (Moses)] said: "O Harun (Aaron)! What stopped you when you saw them going astray;

translation.author: Maududi
translation.text: (After rebuking his people) Moses turned to Aaron and said: "Aaron! What prevented you, when you saw them going astray,

translation.author: Mubarakpuri
translation.text: (Musa) said: "O Harun! What prevented you when you saw them going astray;"

translation.author: Pickthall
translation.text: He (Moses) said: O Aaron! What held thee back when thou didst see them gone astray,

translation.author: Qaribullah & Darwish
translation.text: He (Moses) said to Aaron: 'When you saw them in error, what prevented you,

translation.author: Saheeh International
translation.text: [Moses] said, "O Aaron, what prevented you, when you saw them going astray,

translation.author: Sarwar
translation.text: Then Moses asked Aaron, "What made you not follow me when you saw them in error?

translation.author: Shakir
translation.text: (Musa) said: O Haroun! what prevented you, when you saw them going astray,

translation.author: Wahiduddin Khan
translation.text: Moses said to Aaron, "What prevented you, when you saw that they had gone astray,

translation.author: Yusuf Ali
translation.text: (Moses) said: "O Aaron! what kept thee back, when thou sawest them going wrong,

translation.author: Ahmed Ali
translation.text: But Pharaoh said: "You have come to accept belief in Him without my permission! This surely is a plot you have hatched to expel the people from the land. You will soon come to know.

translation.author: Arberry
translation.text: Said Pharaoh, 'You have believed in Him before I gave you leave. Surely this is a device you have devised in the city that you may expel its people from it. Now you shall know!

translation.author: Hilali & Khan
translation.text: Fir'aun (Pharaoh) said: "You have believed in him [Musa (Moses)] before I give you permission. Surely, this is a plot which you have plotted in the city to drive out its people, but you shall come to know.

translation.author: Itani
translation.text: Pharaoh said, “Did you believe in Him before I have given you permission? This is surely a conspiracy you schemed in the city, in order to expel its people from it. You will surely know.”

translation.author: Maududi
translation.text: Pharaoh said: 'What! Do you believe before you have my permission? Surely this is a plot you have contrived to drive out the rulers from the capital. So you shall see,

translation.author: Mubarakpuri
translation.text: Fir`awn said: "You have believed in him [Musa] before I gave you permission. Surely, this is a plot which you have plotted in the city to drive out its people, but you shall come to know."

translation.author: Pickthall
translation.text: Pharaoh said: Ye believe in Him before I give you leave! Lo! this is the plot that ye have plotted in the city that ye may drive its people hence. But ye shall come to know!

translation.author: Qarai
translation.text: Pharaoh said, ‘Do you profess faith in Him before I may permit you? It is indeed a plot you have devised in the city to expel its people from it. Soon you will know [the consequences]!

translation.author: Qaribullah & Darwish
translation.text: Pharaoh said: 'Do you believe in Him before I permit? This is a plot that you have contrived in the city in order to expel its people from it. Now you shall know!

translation.author: Saheeh International
translation.text: Said Pharaoh, "You believed in him before I gave you permission. Indeed, this is a conspiracy which you conspired in the city to expel therefrom its people. But you are going to know.

translation.author: Sarwar
translation.text: The Pharaoh said to the magicians, "You declared your belief in him (Moses) without my permission. This is a plot to throw my people out of their city. But you will soon know.

translation.author: Wahiduddin Khan
translation.text: Pharaoh said, "You dare believe in Him before I have given you permission? Behold, this is indeed a plot which you have devised in this city in order to drive its people out. But you shall soon know the consequences,

translation.author: Yusuf Ali
translation.text: Said Pharaoh: "Believe ye in Him before I give you permission? Surely this is a trick which ye have planned in the city to drive out its people: but soon shall ye know (the consequences).

translation.author: Ahmed Ali
translation.text: "Bring the cleverest magicians to me," said the Pharaoh.

translation.author: Arberry
translation.text: Pharaoh said, 'Bring me every cunning sorcerer.'

translation.author: Hilali & Khan
translation.text: And Fir'aun (Pharaoh) said: "Bring to me every well-versed sorcerer."

translation.author: Itani
translation.text: Pharaoh said, “Bring me every experienced sorcerer.”

translation.author: Maududi
translation.text: And Pharaoh said (to his) men: 'Bring every skilled sorcerer to me.'

translation.author: Pickthall
translation.text: And Pharaoh said: Bring every cunning wizard unto me.

translation.author: Qarai
translation.text: Pharaoh said, ‘Bring me every expert magician.’

translation.author: Qaribullah & Darwish
translation.text: (Then) Pharaoh said: 'Bring every skilled sorcerer'

translation.author: Saheeh International
translation.text: And Pharaoh said, "Bring to me every learned magician."

translation.author: Sarwar
translation.text: The Pharaoh ordered every skillful magician to come into his presence.

translation.author: Wahiduddin Khan
translation.text: Then Pharaoh said, "Bring me every skilled magician!"

translation.author: Yusuf Ali
translation.text: Said Pharaoh: "Bring me every sorcerer well versed."

translation.author: Ahmed Ali
translation.text: And We brought the people of Israel across the sea, but the Pharaoh and his army pursued them wickedly and maliciously till he was on the point of drowning, and he said: "I believe that there is no god but He in whom the people of Israel believe, and I submit to Him."

translation.author: Arberry
translation.text: And We brought the Children of Israel over the sea; and Pharaoh and his hosts followed them insolently and impetuously till, when the drowning overtook him, he said, 'I believe that there is no god but He in whom the Children of Israel believe; I am of those that surrender.'

translation.author: Hilali & Khan
translation.text: And We took the Children of Israel across the sea, and Fir'aun (Pharaoh) with his hosts followed them in oppression and enmity, till when drowning overtook him, he said: "I believe that La ilaha illa (Huwa): (none has the right to be worshipped but) He," in Whom the Children of Israel believe, and I am one of the Muslims (those who submit to Allah's Will)."

translation.author: Itani
translation.text: And We delivered the Children of Israel across the sea. Pharaoh and his troops pursued them, defiantly and aggressively. Until, when he was about to drown, he said, “I believe that there is no god except the One the Children of Israel believe in, and I am of those who submit.”

translation.author: Maududi
translation.text: And We led the Children of Israel across the sea. Then Pharaoh and his hosts pursued them in iniquity and transgression until Pharaoh cried out while he was drowning: 'I believe that there is no god but Allah in Whom the Children of Israel believe, and I am also one of those who submit to Allah.

translation.author: Pickthall
translation.text: And We brought the Children of Israel across the sea, and Pharaoh with his hosts pursued them in rebellion and transgression, till, when the (fate of) drowning overtook him, he exclaimed: I believe that there is no Allah save Him in Whom the Children of Israel believe, and I am of those who surrender (unto Him).

translation.author: Qarai
translation.text: We carried the Children of Israel across the sea, whereat Pharaoh and his troops pursued them, out of defiance and aggression. When overtaken by drowning, he called out, ‘I believe that there is no god except Him in whom the Children of Israel believe, and I am one of those who submit [to Him]!’

translation.author: Qaribullah & Darwish
translation.text: We brought the Children of Israel through the sea, and Pharaoh and his legions pursued them arrogantly and frantically. But as he was drowning he cried out: '(Now) I believe that there is no god except He in whom the Children of Israel believe. I am of those that surrender (Muslims)'

translation.author: Saheeh International
translation.text: And We took the Children of Israel across the sea, and Pharaoh and his soldiers pursued them in tyranny and enmity until, when drowning overtook him, he said, "I believe that there is no deity except that in whom the Children of Israel believe, and I am of the Muslims."

translation.author: Sarwar
translation.text: We helped the children of Israel cross the sea safely. The Pharaoh and his army pursued the children of Israel with wickedness and hate until the Pharaoh was drowned. As he was drowning the Pharaoh said, "I declare that there is no God but the One in whom the children of Israel believe and I have submitted to the Word of God".

translation.author: Wahiduddin Khan
translation.text: So We brought the Children of Israel across the sea. Pharaoh and his troops pursued them arrogantly and aggressively. When he was about to drown, [Pharaoh] exclaimed, "I believe that there is no deity save Him in whom the Children of Israel believe, and I am of those who surrender themselves to Him!"

translation.author: Yusuf Ali
translation.text: We took the Children of Israel across the sea: Pharaoh and his hosts followed them in insolence and spite. At length, when overwhelmed with the flood, he said: "I believe that there is no god except Him Whom the Children of Israel believe in: I am of those who submit (to Allah in Islam)."

translation.author: Ahmed Ali
translation.text: To the Pharaoh and his nobles, but they followed the bidding of Pharaoh, though the bidding of Pharaoh was unrightful.

translation.author: Arberry
translation.text: to Pharaoh and his Council; but they followed Pharaoh's command, and Pharaoh's command was not right-minded.

translation.author: Hilali & Khan
translation.text: To Fir'aun (Pharaoh) and his chiefs, but they followed the command of Fir'aun (Pharaoh), and the command of Fir'aun (Pharaoh) was no right guide.

translation.author: Itani
translation.text: To Pharaoh and his nobles, but they followed the command of Pharaoh, and the command of Pharaoh was not wise.

translation.author: Maududi
translation.text: to Pharaoh and his nobles. But they obeyed the command of Pharaoh even though Pharaoh's command was not rightly-directed.

translation.author: Pickthall
translation.text: Unto Pharaoh and his chiefs, but they did follow the command of Pharaoh, and the command of Pharaoh was no right guide.

translation.author: Qarai
translation.text: to Pharaoh and his elite, but they followed Pharaoh’s dictates, and Pharaoh’s dictates were not right-minded.

translation.author: Qaribullah & Darwish
translation.text: to Pharaoh and his Council. But they followed the command of Pharaoh, and Pharaoh's command was not rightminded.

translation.author: Saheeh International
translation.text: To Pharaoh and his establishment, but they followed the command of Pharaoh, and the command of Pharaoh was not [at all] discerning.

translation.author: Sarwar
translation.text: They followed the order of the Pharaoh but Pharaoh's orders were evil.

translation.author: Wahiduddin Khan
translation.text: to Pharaoh and his nobles. But they followed the command of Pharaoh and the command of Pharaoh was not rightly directed.

translation.author: Yusuf Ali
translation.text: Unto Pharaoh and his chiefs: but they followed the command of Pharaoh and the command of Pharaoh was no right (guide).

translation.author: Ahmed Ali
translation.text: The two went on till they came to a boy, whom he killed. Moses exclaimed: "You have killed an innocent soul who had taken no life. You have done a most abominable thing!"

translation.author: Daryabadi
translation.text: Then the twain journeyed until when they met a boy, and he killed him. Musa said: hast thou slain a person innocent not in return for a Person Assuredly thou hast committed a thing formidable.

translation.author: Hilali & Khan
translation.text: Then they both proceeded, till they met a boy, he (Khidr) killed him. Musa (Moses) said: "Have you killed an innocent person who had killed none? Verily, you have committed a thing "Nukra" (a great Munkar - prohibited, evil, dreadful thing)!"

translation.author: Maududi
translation.text: Then the two went forth until they met a lad whom he slew, whereupon Moses exclaimed: "What! Have you slain an innocent person without his having slain anyone? Surely you have done a horrible thing."

translation.author: Mubarakpuri
translation.text: Then they both proceeded till they met a boy, and he (Khidr) killed him. Musa said: "Have you killed an innocent person without Nafs Verily, you have committed a thing Nukr!"

translation.author: Pickthall
translation.text: So they twain journeyed on till, when they met a lad, he slew him. (Moses) said: What! Hast thou slain an innocent soul who hath slain no man? Verily thou hast done a horrid thing.

translation.author: Qaribullah & Darwish
translation.text: and so they departed. Thereafter they met a boy and he killed him. He (Moses) exclaimed: 'What, have you killed a pure soul and it was not done (in retaliation) for a soul you have done a terrible thing'

translation.author: Saheeh International
translation.text: So they set out, until when they met a boy, al-Khidh r killed him. [Moses] said, "Have you killed a pure soul for other than [having killed] a soul? You have certainly done a deplorable thing."

translation.author: Sarwar
translation.text: They continued on their journey until they met a young boy whom he killed. Moses said, "How could you murder an innocent soul? This is certainly a horrible act".

translation.author: Shakir
translation.text: So they went on until, when they met a boy, he slew him. (Musa) said: Have you slain an innocent person otherwise than for manslaughter? Certainly you have done an evil thing.

translation.author: Wahiduddin Khan
translation.text: So they travelled on. Then they met a young boy and the man killed him. Moses said, "Have you slain an innocent person without his having slain anyone? Indeed, you have done a terrible thing!"

translation.author: Yusuf Ali
translation.text: Then they proceeded: until, when they met a young man, he slew him. Moses said: "Hast thou slain an innocent person who had slain none? Truly a foul (unheard of) thing hast thou done!"

translation.author: Ahmed Ali
translation.text: The two went on till they came upon some villagers, and asked the people for food, but they refused to entertain them. There they found a wall that was crumbling, which he repaired. Moses remarked: "You could have demanded wages for it if you liked."

translation.author: Daryabadi
translation.text: Then the twain journeyed until when they came unto the people of a city, they begged food from the people thereof, but they refused to entertain the twain. Then they found therein a wall, about to fall down, and he set it upright. Musa said: hadst thou willed, thou mightest have taken therefor a hire.

translation.author: Hilali & Khan
translation.text: Then they both proceeded, till, when they came to the people of a town, they asked them for food, but they refused to entertain them. Then they found therein a wall about to collapse and he (Khidr) set it up straight. [Musa (Moses)] said: If you had wished, surely, you could have taken wages for it!"

translation.author: Maududi
translation.text: Then the two went forth until when they came to a town, they asked its people for food, but they refused to play host to them. They found in that town a wall that was on the verge of tumbling down, and he buttressed it, whereupon Moses said: "If you had wished, you could have received payment for it."

translation.author: Mubarakpuri
translation.text: Then they both proceeded till when they came to the people of a town, they asked them for food, but they refused to entertain them. Then they found therein a wall about to collapse and he set it up straight. (Musa) said: "If you had wished, surely you could have taken wages for it!"

translation.author: Pickthall
translation.text: So they twain journeyed on till, when they came unto the folk of a certain township, they asked its folk for food, but they refused to make them guests. And they found therein a wall upon the point of falling into ruin, and he repaired it. (Moses) said: If thou hadst wished, thou couldst have taken payment for it.

translation.author: Qaribullah & Darwish
translation.text: So they departed and thereafter they came to the inhabitants of a village. They asked its inhabitants for some food, but they declined to host them. There, they found a wall about to fall down whereupon his companion restored it. He (Moses) said: 'Had you wished, you could have taken payment for that'

translation.author: Saheeh International
translation.text: So they set out, until when they came to the people of a town, they asked its people for food, but they refused to offer them hospitality. And they found therein a wall about to collapse, so al-Khidh r restored it. [Moses] said, "If you wished, you could have taken for it a payment."

translation.author: Sarwar
translation.text: They continued on their journey again until they reached a town. They asked the people there for food, but no one accepted them as their guests. They found there a wall of a house which was on the verge of tumbling to the ground. The companion of Moses repaired that wall. Moses said, "You should have received some money for your labor."

translation.author: Shakir
translation.text: So they went on until when they came to the people of a town, they asked them for food, but they refused to entertain them as guests. Then they found in it a wall which was on the point of falling, so he put it into a right state. (Musa) said: If you had pleased, you might certainly have taken a recompense for it.

translation.author: Wahiduddin Khan
translation.text: So they went on until they came to a town. They asked its people for food, but were refused hospitality. They found a wall in the town which was about to fall down. His companion buttressed it and Moses said, "Had you wished, you could have demanded payment for your labours."

translation.author: Yusuf Ali
translation.text: Then they proceeded: until, when they came to the inhabitants of a town, they asked them for food, but they refused them hospitality. They found there a wall on the point of falling down, but he set it up straight. (Moses) said: "If thou hadst wished, surely thou couldst have exacted some recompense for it!"

translation.author: Ahmed Ali
translation.text: Go to the Pharaoh as he has become exceedingly rebellious."

translation.author: Arberry
translation.text: Go to Pharaoh; he has waxed insolent.'

translation.author: Hilali & Khan
translation.text: "Go to Fir'aun (Pharaoh)! Verily, he has transgressed (all bounds in disbelief and disobedience, and has behaved as an arrogant, and as a tyrant)."

translation.author: Itani
translation.text: Go to Pharaoh; He has transgressed.”

translation.author: Maududi
translation.text: And go to Pharaoh now for he has transgressed all bounds."

translation.author: Pickthall
translation.text: Go thou unto Pharaoh! Lo! he hath transgressed (the bounds).

translation.author: Qarai
translation.text: Go to Pharaoh. He has indeed rebelled.’

translation.author: Qaribullah & Darwish
translation.text: 24 Go to Pharaoh, he has become insolent'

translation.author: Saheeh International
translation.text: Go to Pharaoh. Indeed, he has transgressed."

translation.author: Sarwar
translation.text: Go to the Pharaoh; he has become a rebel."

translation.author: Wahiduddin Khan
translation.text: Go to Pharaoh; he has transgressed all bounds."

translation.author: Yusuf Ali
translation.text: "Go thou to Pharaoh, for he has indeed transgressed all bounds."

translation.author: Ahmed Ali
translation.text: Then go to the Pharaoh as he has become exceedingly rebellious.

translation.author: Arberry
translation.text: Go to Pharaoh, for he has waxed insolent;

translation.author: Hilali & Khan
translation.text: "Go, both of you, to Fir'aun (Pharaoh), verily, he has transgressed (all bounds in disbelief and disobedience and behaved as an arrogant and as a tyrant).

translation.author: Itani
translation.text: Go to Pharaoh. He has tyrannized.

translation.author: Maududi
translation.text: Go both of you to Pharaoh, for he has transgressed all bounds,

translation.author: Pickthall
translation.text: Go, both of you, unto Pharaoh. Lo! he hath transgressed (the bounds).

translation.author: Qarai
translation.text: Both of you go to Pharaoh, for he has indeed rebelled.

translation.author: Qaribullah & Darwish
translation.text: Go to Pharaoh, for he has become insolent.

translation.author: Saheeh International
translation.text: Go, both of you, to Pharaoh. Indeed, he has transgressed.

translation.author: Sarwar
translation.text: Go both of you to the Pharaoh; he has become a rebel.

translation.author: Wahiduddin Khan
translation.text: Go, both of you to Pharaoh, for he has transgressed all bounds.

translation.author: Yusuf Ali
translation.text: "Go, both of you, to Pharaoh, for he has indeed transgressed all bounds;

translation.author: Ahmed Ali
translation.text: After this the Pharaoh withdrew and settled his stratagem, then came back.

translation.author: Arberry
translation.text: Pharaoh then withdrew, and gathered his guile. Thereafter he came again,

translation.author: Hilali & Khan
translation.text: So Fir'aun (Pharaoh) withdrew, devised his plot and then came back.

translation.author: Itani
translation.text: Pharaoh turned away, put together his plan, and then came back.

translation.author: Maududi
translation.text: Pharaoh went back and concerted all his stratagem and returned for the encounter.

translation.author: Pickthall
translation.text: Then Pharaoh went and gathered his strength, then came (to the appointed tryst).

translation.author: Qarai
translation.text: Then Pharaoh withdrew [to consult privately], summoned up his guile, and then arrived [at the scene of the contest].

translation.author: Qaribullah & Darwish
translation.text: So Pharaoh withdrew and gathered his guile, then returned,

translation.author: Saheeh International
translation.text: So Pharaoh went away, put together his plan, and then came [to Moses].

translation.author: Sarwar
translation.text: The Pharaoh returned to organize his plans and then attended the appointment.

translation.author: Wahiduddin Khan
translation.text: So Pharaoh withdrew, devised his stratagem and returned.

translation.author: Yusuf Ali
translation.text: So Pharaoh withdrew: He concerted his plan, and then came (back).

translation.author: Ahmed Ali
translation.text: Then the Pharaoh followed them with his army, but the sea overpowered and engulfed them.

translation.author: Arberry
translation.text: Pharaoh followed them with his hosts, but they were overwhelmed by the sea;

translation.author: Hilali & Khan
translation.text: Then Fir'aun (Pharaoh) pursued them with his hosts, but the sea-water completely overwhelmed them and covered them up.

translation.author: Itani
translation.text: Pharaoh pursued them with his troops, but the sea overwhelmed them, and completely engulfed them.

translation.author: Maududi
translation.text: Pharaoh pursued them with his hosts, but they were fully overwhelmed by the sea.

translation.author: Pickthall
translation.text: Then Pharaoh followed them with his hosts and there covered them that which did cover them of the sea.

translation.author: Qarai
translation.text: Then Pharaoh pursued them with his troops, whereat they were engulfed by what engulfed them of the sea.

translation.author: Qaribullah & Darwish
translation.text: Pharaoh pursued them with his legions so they were overwhelmed from the sea with that which drowned them.

translation.author: Saheeh International
translation.text: So Pharaoh pursued them with his soldiers, and there covered them from the sea that which covered them,

translation.author: Sarwar
translation.text: The Pharaoh and his army chased Moses and his people but were drowned by the sea.

translation.author: Wahiduddin Khan
translation.text: Pharaoh pursued them with his hosts, but they were submerged by the sea, which was destined to overwhelm them.

translation.author: Yusuf Ali
translation.text: Then Pharaoh pursued them with his forces, but the waters completely overwhelmed them and covered them up.

translation.author: Ahmed Ali
translation.text: The Pharaoh had led his people astray, and did not rightly guide them.

translation.author: Arberry
translation.text: so Pharaoh had led his people astray, and was no guide to them.

translation.author: Hilali & Khan
translation.text: And Fir'aun (Pharaoh) led his people astray, and he did not guide them.

translation.author: Itani
translation.text: Pharaoh misled his people, and did not guide them.

translation.author: Maududi
translation.text: Pharaoh led his people astray; he did not guide them aright.

translation.author: Pickthall
translation.text: And Pharaoh led his folk astray, he did not guide them.

translation.author: Qarai
translation.text: Pharaoh led his people astray and did not guide them.

translation.author: Qaribullah & Darwish
translation.text: For Pharaoh had misled his nation, and did not guide them.

translation.author: Saheeh International
translation.text: And Pharaoh led his people astray and did not guide [them].

translation.author: Sarwar
translation.text: The Pharaoh and his people had gone away from guidance.

translation.author: Wahiduddin Khan
translation.text: For Pharaoh had led his people astray and did not guide them.

translation.author: Yusuf Ali
translation.text: Pharaoh led his people astray instead of leading them aright.

translation.author: Ahmed Ali
translation.text: Moses asked: "O Sameri, what was the matter?"

translation.author: Arberry
translation.text: Moses said, 'And thou, Samaritan, what was thy business?'

translation.author: Daryabadi
translation.text: Musa said: what was thy object, O Samiri?

translation.author: Hilali & Khan
translation.text: [Musa (Moses)] said: "And what is the matter with you. O Samiri? (i.e. why did you do so?)"

translation.author: Maududi
translation.text: Moses said: "What, then, is your case, O Samiri?"

translation.author: Mubarakpuri
translation.text: (Musa) said: "And what is the matter with you. O Samiri"

translation.author: Pickthall
translation.text: (Moses) said: And what hast thou to say, O Samiri?

translation.author: Qaribullah & Darwish
translation.text: 'You, Samaritan' said he (Moses), 'what was your business'

translation.author: Saheeh International
translation.text: [Moses] said, "And what is your case, O Samiri?"

translation.author: Sarwar
translation.text: Moses asked, "Samiri, what were your motives?"

translation.author: Wahiduddin Khan
translation.text: Moses said, "What was the matter with you, Samiri?"

translation.author: Yusuf Ali
translation.text: (Moses) said: "What then is thy case, O Samiri?"

translation.author: Ahmed Ali
translation.text: (Moses) said: "Go hence! All your life you are (cursed) to say: 'Do not touch me; and a threat hangs over you which you will not be able to escape. Look at your god to whom you are so attached: We shall verily burn it, and disperse its ashes into the sea.

translation.author: Arberry
translation.text: 'Depart!' said Moses. 'It shall be thine all this life to cry "Untouchable!" And thereafter a tryst awaits thee thou canst not fail to keep Behold thy god, to whom all the day thou wast cleaving! We will surely burn it and scatter its ashes into the sea.

translation.author: Daryabadi
translation.text: Musa said: begone thou! verily it shall be thine in life to say no contact; and verily thine is an appointment which thou shalt by no means fail. And look at thy god to which thou hast been assidauous; we shall surely burn it, and we shall scatter it into the sea a wide scattering.

translation.author: Hilali & Khan
translation.text: Musa (Moses) said: "Then go away! And verily, your (punishment) in this life will be that you will say: "Touch me not (i.e. you will live alone exiled away from mankind); and verily (for a future torment), you have a promise that will not fail. And look at your ilah (god), to which you have been devoted. We will certainly burn it, and scatter its particles in the sea."

translation.author: Maududi
translation.text: Moses said: "Be gone, then. All your life you shall cry: 'Untouchable.' There awaits a term for your reckoning that you cannot fail to keep. Now look at your god that you devotedly adored: We shall burn it and scatter its remains in the sea.

translation.author: Mubarakpuri
translation.text: Musa said: "Then go away! And verily, your (punishment) in this life will be that you will say: `Touch me not;' and verily, you have a promise that will not fail. And look at your god to which you have been devoted. We will certainly burn it, and scatter its particles in the sea."

translation.author: Pickthall
translation.text: (Moses) said: Then go! and lo! in this life it is for thee to say: Touch me not! and lo! there is for thee a tryst thou canst not break. Now look upon thy god of which thou hast remained a votary. Verily we will burn it and will scatter its dust over the sea.

translation.author: Qaribullah & Darwish
translation.text: 'Begone! Your lot in this life is to cry: "untouchable!' said he (Moses). 'An appointment awaits you that you cannot fail to keep. Look at your god which you clung to indeed we will burn it and scatter its ashes upon the sea'

translation.author: Saheeh International
translation.text: [Moses] said, "Then go. And indeed, it is [decreed] for you in [this] life to say, 'No contact.' And indeed, you have an appointment [in the Hereafter] you will not fail to keep. And look at your 'god' to which you remained devoted. We will surely burn it and blow it into the sea with a blast.

translation.author: Sarwar
translation.text: Moses said, "Go away! Throughout your life you will not be able to let anyone touch you. This will be your punishment in this life. The time for your final punishment is inevitable. You will never be able to avoid it. Look at your god which you have been worshipping. We will burn it in the fire and scatter its ashes into the sea."

translation.author: Wahiduddin Khan
translation.text: Moses said, "Begone! It shall be your lot to say throughout your life, "Do not touch me," and you will be faced with a fate from which there will be no escape. Now look at your deity to which you have become so devoted: we shall burn it up, and then scatter it into the sea.

translation.author: Yusuf Ali
translation.text: (Moses) said: "Get thee gone! but thy (punishment) in this life will be that thou wilt say, 'touch me not'; and moreover (for a future penalty) thou hast a promise that will not fail: Now look at thy god, of whom thou hast become a devoted worshipper: We will certainly (melt) it in a blazing fire and scatter it broadcast in the sea!"

translation.author: Ahmed Ali
translation.text: To Pharaoh and his nobles who behaved with arrogance, for they were a conceited lot,

translation.author: Arberry
translation.text: unto Pharaoh and his Council; but they waxed proud, and they were a lofty people,

translation.author: Hilali & Khan
translation.text: To Fir'aun (Pharaoh) and his chiefs, but they behaved insolently and they were people self-exalting (by disobeying their Lord, and exalting themselves over and above the Messenger of Allah).

translation.author: Itani
translation.text: To Pharaoh and his nobles, but they turned arrogant. They were oppressive people.

translation.author: Maududi
translation.text: to Pharaoh and to his chiefs, but they behaved superciliously and they were haughty.

translation.author: Pickthall
translation.text: Unto Pharaoh and his chiefs, but they scorned (them) and they were despotic folk.

translation.author: Qarai
translation.text: to Pharaoh and his elites; but they acted arrogantly and they were a tyrannical lot.

translation.author: Qaribullah & Darwish
translation.text: to Pharaoh and his Council, but they were very proud, and they were a tyrannical nation.

translation.author: Saheeh International
translation.text: To Pharaoh and his establishment, but they were arrogant and were a haughty people.

translation.author: Sarwar
translation.text: to the Pharaoh and his nobles. But they behaved proudly and thought themselves superior people.

translation.author: Wahiduddin Khan
translation.text: to Pharaoh and his courtiers, but they behaved insolently, for they were an arrogant people.

translation.author: Yusuf Ali
translation.text: To Pharaoh and his Chiefs: But these behaved insolently: they were an arrogant people.

translation.author: Ahmed Ali
translation.text: Go to the Pharaoh and tell him: 'We bring a message from the Lord of all the worlds

translation.author: Arberry
translation.text: So go you to Pharaoh, and say, "Verily, I am the Messenger of the Lord of all Being;

translation.author: Hilali & Khan
translation.text: "And when you both come to Fir'aun (Pharaoh), say: 'We are the Messengers of the Lord of the 'Alamin (mankind, jinns and all that exists),

translation.author: Itani
translation.text: Go to Pharaoh, and say, ‘We are the Messengers of the Lord of the Worlds.

translation.author: Maududi
translation.text: Go, then, to Pharaoh and say to him: 'The Lord of the Universe has sent us

translation.author: Pickthall
translation.text: And come together unto Pharaoh and say: Lo! we bear a message of the Lord of the Worlds,

translation.author: Qarai
translation.text: So approach Pharaoh and say, ‘‘We are indeed envoys of the Lord of the worlds

translation.author: Qaribullah & Darwish
translation.text: go both to Pharaoh and both of you say to him: 'We are (each) a Messenger from the Lord of all the Worlds.

translation.author: Saheeh International
translation.text: Go to Pharaoh and say, 'We are the messengers of the Lord of the worlds,

translation.author: Sarwar
translation.text: They came to the Pharaoh and said, "We are the Messengerss of the Lord of the Universe.

translation.author: Wahiduddin Khan
translation.text: Go to Pharaoh, both of you, and say, 'We are messengers from the Lord of the Worlds:

translation.author: Yusuf Ali
translation.text: "So go forth, both of you, to Pharaoh, and say: 'We have been sent by the Lord and Cherisher of the worlds;

translation.author: Ahmed Ali
translation.text: When the magicians arrived, they said to the Pharaoh: "Is there a reward for us if we are victorious?" --

translation.author: Arberry
translation.text: Then, when the sorcerers came, they said to Pharaoh, 'Shall we indeed have a wage, if we should be the victors?'

translation.author: Hilali & Khan
translation.text: So when the sorcerers arrived, they said to Fir'aun (Pharaoh): "Will there surely be a reward for us if we are the winners?"

translation.author: Itani
